Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there was no evidence of Russian collusion in the Paul Manafort case, as stated by the sentencing judge.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the two courts ruling by stating that "two courts have ruled no evidence of any collusion with any Russians," when in fact, the judge did not rule on collusion and the other court's ruling is unrelated to collusion.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that there was no evidence of Russian collusion in the case, as the judge did not make such a ruling.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the absence of evidence of Russian collusion in the Paul Manafort case implies the absence of collusion in the broader Trump campaign.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that the absence of evidence of collusion in the Paul Manafort case does not necessarily mean there was no collusion in other aspects of the Trump campaign.
